Bug.Summery: Applying a patch

Lines.Line: - there should be an action "Apply Patch" in the team menu. It is hard to
understand that I have to active "Compare Patch" to apply a patch.
- the wizard that pops up should guide me through the process of applying the
patch.
First page: like the current one. The only thing that suprised me a little bit
is the fact that when I create a patch for a folder I have to apply the same
patch to the project. The reason for this is that the index entry is always
relative to the project even if I create it for a folder.
Second page to find best patch settings: using check boxes to indicate that a
patch item can be applied is strange. I would prefer having a error icon
instead. When selecting an item that can be applied I would like to
see that applied patch (compare current source with source that has applied
patch) instead of seeing the content of the patch. If the user checks an
item that can't be applied then the Next and Finish button is disabled.
Third page (currently not present): contains an compare editor showing the
current source and the source with checked patches applied. I was really
suprised that I got a separate editor for this and the dialog was
closed. Best would be if the editor in that dialog would be editable.
One the second page there should be a sash between the check box tree viewer
and the compare viewer
The third page should show me the *.rej file if produced like the current
compare editor does
the other items after 2.1
I don't believe any of these comments apply to the current Apply Patch wizard
As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported.
Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.WithStack:
The current way how to apply a patch isn't very intuitive. At least it wasn't for me. Here is what I think could improve it:
- there should be an action "Apply Patch" in the team menu. It is hard to understand that I have to active "Compare Patch" to apply a patch. - the wizard that pops up should guide me through the process of applying the patch. First page: like the current one. The only thing that suprised me a little bit is the fact that when I create a patch for a folder I have to apply the same patch to the project. The reason for this is that the index entry is always relative to the project even if I create it for a folder. Second page to find best patch settings: using check boxes to indicate that a patch item can be applied is strange. I would prefer having a error icon instead. When selecting an item that can be applied I would like to see that applied patch (compare current source with source that has applied patch) instead of seeing the content of the patch. If the user checks an item that can't be applied then the Next and Finish button is disabled. Third page (currently not present): contains an compare editor showing the current source and the source with checked patches applied. I was really suprised that I got a separate editor for this and the dialog was closed. Best would be if the editor in that dialog would be editable. One the second page there should be a sash between the check box tree viewer and the compare viewer The third page should show me the *.rej file if produced like the current compare editor does for 2.1 M5 see #29791, the other items after 2.1 I don't believe any of these comments apply to the current Apply Patch wizard As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Drag to windows explorer moves file but file remains in Navigator

Lines.Line: 1. Drag a file from Eclipse Navigator to Windows Explorer
==> file still visible in Eclipse even though the file was moved in the FS
2. Do some operation on the file (e.g. rename)
==> Problem dialog
This requires support from SWT.
This has been supported in SWT since Oct 22, 2001.
See bug report http://dev.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=4831
- delete
- move
- setContents
- appendContents
But in this case we are not calling any API. The OS (the drag target) does the
move. So I have to copy the file to the local history before the file gets
moved by the OS. Getting the contents and than setting the same contents could
do the trick but it looks like a hack.
Need to handle DND.DROP_TARGET_MOVE and do a refresh on the workspace file,
because the OS is moving the file under us in this case.
There will be no local history in this case.
This is a dup PR.

Bug.WithStack:
1. Drag a file from Eclipse Navigator to Windows Explorer ==> file still visible in Eclipse even though the file was moved in the FS 2. Do some operation on the file (e.g. rename) ==> Problem dialog This requires support from SWT. This has been supported in SWT since Oct 22, 2001. See bug report http://dev.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=4831
The fix is for the Navigator to detect the case and handle it accordingly
public void dragFinished(DragSourceEvent event){ if (event.detail == DND.DROP_TARGET_MOVE) { // fix the Navigator display but do not delete the file } ... } We need to copy the file to the local history on dragSetData and to a refresh from local on dragFinished.
Need to check if there is API to copy a file to local history. There is no Core API to explicitly add a file to the local history.
This is taken care of automatically (in conjuction with specifying the KEEP_HISTORY flag) when you perform other operations which modify the contents of the file. History is (optionally) kept for: - delete - move - setContents - appendContents But in this case we are not calling any API. The OS (the drag target) does the move. So I have to copy the file to the local history before the file gets moved by the OS. Getting the contents and than setting the same contents could do the trick but it looks like a hack. Need to handle DND.DROP_TARGET_MOVE and do a refresh on the workspace file, because the OS is moving the file under us in this case. There will be no local history in this case. This is a dup PR.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 12718 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
1. Drag a file from Eclipse Navigator to Windows Explorer ==> file still visible in Eclipse even though the file was moved in the FS 2. Do some operation on the file (e.g. rename) ==> Problem dialog This requires support from SWT. This has been supported in SWT since Oct 22, 2001. See bug report http://dev.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=4831
The fix is for the Navigator to detect the case and handle it accordingly
public void dragFinished(DragSourceEvent event){ if (event.detail == DND.DROP_TARGET_MOVE) { // fix the Navigator display but do not delete the file } ... } We need to copy the file to the local history on dragSetData and to a refresh from local on dragFinished.
Need to check if there is API to copy a file to local history. There is no Core API to explicitly add a file to the local history.
This is taken care of automatically (in conjuction with specifying the KEEP_HISTORY flag) when you perform other operations which modify the contents of the file. History is (optionally) kept for: - delete - move - setContents - appendContents But in this case we are not calling any API. The OS (the drag target) does the move. So I have to copy the file to the local history before the file gets moved by the OS. Getting the contents and than setting the same contents could do the trick but it looks like a hack. Need to handle DND.DROP_TARGET_MOVE and do a refresh on the workspace file, because the OS is moving the file under us in this case. There will be no local history in this case. This is a dup PR.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 12718 ***

Bug.Summery: Banner graphics have white background
Bug.WithStack:
On my linux machine the defualt background color for labels is grey. The banner grapbics (wizards, welcome page, preference dialog etc.) have a white background which makes them stand out. A transparent background is probably not a ggod idea so we may be stuck with this problem. This is fixed right? The thing that was changed is that we no longer slam the background colour to match the icon. The icon currently has a white background and would need to be replaced with a transparent icon to match settings with non white labels.

Bug.Summery: IncompatibleThreadStateException displayed in Detail pane when thread manually suspended
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020122
If you suspend a thread manually (i.e. by pressing the suspend button), and select a variable, the Detail pane will show <com.sun.jdi.IncompatibleThreadStateException>.
This is because JDI doesn't allow to perform an invocation on a thread that has not been suspended by jdi request.
Maybe a more explicit message indicating the limitation should be displayed instead. Fixed.
Note, I found a new bug while fixing this one (bug# 14283) Please verify. The first time I select the variable I get a error message: [toString() unavailable - thread must be suspended by breakpoint or step] (id=24) This is a great improvement, but I think we could lose the (id=24) part?
If I reselect the variable, I get: com.sun.jdi.IncompatibleThreadStateException occurred invoking method. (id=24)
Is this intended? This is a bug. Fixed (and removed (id = X)). please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020122
If you suspend a thread manually (i.e. by pressing the suspend button), and select a variable, the Detail pane will show <com.sun.jdi.IncompatibleThreadStateException>.
This is because JDI doesn't allow to perform an invocation on a thread that has not been suspended by jdi request.
Maybe a more explicit message indicating the limitation should be displayed instead. Fixed.
Note, I found a new bug while fixing this one (bug# 14283) Please verify. The first time I select the variable I get a error message: [toString() unavailable - thread must be suspended by breakpoint or step] (id=24) This is a great improvement, but I think we could lose the (id=24) part?
If I reselect the variable, I get: com.sun.jdi.IncompatibleThreadStateException occurred invoking method. (id=24)
Is this intended? This is a bug. Fixed (and removed (id = X)). please verify. Verified.

Bug.Summery: [misc] links in Javadoc hovers

Lines.Line: - @docRoot
- relative links (<a href="../file.html")
*** Bug 233243 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Bug 233243 contains a (not yet fully working) patch for @docRoot.
Created attachment 105493
Fix for {@docRoot} and relative links
- an improved version of the @docRoot patch from bug 233243
- fix for relative links (sets the head > base tag)
- a workaround for bug 237903 to make relative links work with Javadoc from the file system

Bug.WithStack:
would be very cool to be able to navigate javadoc by clicking on a link (like @see .....) agreed, but not for 2.0 Reopening for 2.1 consideration *** Bug 120611 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 46696 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 138161 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 200688 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 212286 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Links have been added, but some of them don't work yet. Known problems: - @docRoot - relative links (<a href="../file.html") *** Bug 233243 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Bug 233243 contains a (not yet fully working) patch for @docRoot. Created attachment 105493 Fix for {@docRoot} and relative links
This patch contains - an improved version of the @docRoot patch from bug 233243 - fix for relative links (sets the head > base tag) - a workaround for bug 237903 to make relative links work with Javadoc from the file system
With Javadoc from an archive, the help system is used to resolve the base URL. This handles 'jar:...' URLs, which would not work otherwise (and we don't have the callback to implement this without a web server, see bug 149022).

Improves the workaround for bug 237903. Released Fix 2 to HEAD. Setting target to 3.4.1 (will decide later whether we will really release it into 3.4.1). Will not backport this to 3.4.1. Relative links are not a big problem for 3.4 users, and it's not a regression. Bug.Summery: Extract Local Variable: Should honor code formatter settings
Bug.WithStack:
20122: The generated code does not honor the code formatter settings: example: created variable assignement String rr="JUnit "+Version.id();
The trick to do this without formatting the user code would be to let the formatter work first on a string containing only generated code: - String rr=xx; -> String rr= xx; - The replace xx with the user code the test case you gave should not be modified - user code was rr="Junit" ... (i.e. not conforming to the setting) - it is preserved that way.
there is, however, a bug in the refactoring: int y= 0+0; now, select the expression (together with the leading space) the new temp declaration is: int temp= 0+0; which is incorrect
(compact assignment pref is on) user code was System.out.println("JUnit "+Version.id()); generated code was String rr="JUnit "+Version.id(); System.out.println(rr);
ok, this i don't believe :) i just checked it on the latest (which is same as 0205) and it works correctly
adopting the bug anyway - the other thing needs fixing after a conversation with MA i know what the problem is: we should not assume that any code formatter preference means this or that (like we assume that 'compact assignment' means a sinle space after the '=' sign). whenever possible we should let the formatter format any generated code.
that way we're much more flexible, not hardcode things (what the above assumptions really are - hardcoding) and will be ready when pluggable code formatters show up.
that is another bug though - see bug#9443 this is fixed - bug#9443 remains open
Bug.WithOutStack:
20122: The generated code does not honor the code formatter settings: example: created variable assignement String rr="JUnit "+Version.id();
The trick to do this without formatting the user code would be to let the formatter work first on a string containing only generated code: - String rr=xx; -> String rr= xx; - The replace xx with the user code the test case you gave should not be modified - user code was rr="Junit" ... (i.e. not conforming to the setting) - it is preserved that way.
there is, however, a bug in the refactoring: int y= 0+0; now, select the expression (together with the leading space) the new temp declaration is: int temp= 0+0; which is incorrect
(compact assignment pref is on) user code was System.out.println("JUnit "+Version.id()); generated code was String rr="JUnit "+Version.id(); System.out.println(rr);
ok, this i don't believe :) i just checked it on the latest (which is same as 0205) and it works correctly
adopting the bug anyway - the other thing needs fixing after a conversation with MA i know what the problem is: we should not assume that any code formatter preference means this or that (like we assume that 'compact assignment' means a sinle space after the '=' sign). whenever possible we should let the formatter format any generated code.
that way we're much more flexible, not hardcode things (what the above assumptions really are - hardcoding) and will be ready when pluggable code formatters show up.
that is another bug though - see bug#9443 this is fixed - bug#9443 remains open

Bug.Summery: 'Could not uniquely map the type name' message opening type

Lines.Line: 1. Create 2 java projects: JUnit1 and JUnit2
2. In each project, add junit.jar and add it to each project's buildpath
3. Add third java project test with both JUnit1 and JUnit2 on its buildpath
4. Delete JUnit2
5. Workbench->Open Type
6. Select AssertionFailedError and press OK
Observe: You get a message dialog saying: 'Could not uniquely map the type name'
PackageFragmentRoot.exists() returns true for root A/Junit1/junit.jar.
Problem is with PackageFragmentRoot.isOnClasspath() that uses isPrefixOf(IPath)
to compare classpath instead of equals(...).
Good find.
Changed from isPrefixOf(...) to equals(...)

Build 20020122
1. Create 2 java projects: JUnit1 and JUnit2 2. In each project, add junit.jar and add it to each project's buildpath 3. Add third java project test with both JUnit1 and JUnit2 on its buildpath 4. Select AssertionFailedError and press OK Observe: You get a message dialog saying: 'Could not uniquely map the type name' PackageFragmentRoot.exists() returns true for root A/Junit1/junit.jar. Problem is with PackageFragmentRoot.isOnClasspath() that uses isPrefixOf(IPath) to compare classpath instead of equals(...). Good find. Changed from isPrefixOf(...) to equals(...)

Bug.Summery: Outline View has mnemonic collison
Bug.WithStack:
Compare With and Add Entry Breakpoint both use A for a mnemonic Not VCM. Moving to JDT. We should be aware that this problem can't be solved in general since these actions are contributed.
All we can do is to avoid clashed inside contributions from the platform. Compare with is used in several context menus and it is challenging to find a mnemonic that doesn't conflict. Please change the mnemonic of Add Entry Breakpoint.
Fixed in ActionMessages. Please verify (Joe) Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Compare With and Add Entry Breakpoint both use A for a mnemonic Not VCM. Moving to JDT. We should be aware that this problem can't be solved in general since these actions are contributed.
All we can do is to avoid clashed inside contributions from the platform. Compare with is used in several context menus and it is challenging to find a mnemonic that doesn't conflict. Please change the mnemonic of Add Entry Breakpoint.
Fixed in ActionMessages. Please verify (Joe) Verified.

Bug.Summery: Widget is disposed error when tabbing on linux
Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse build 20020122-I
Use Ctrl tab to get to Combo box in toolbar. Use Ctrl arrow key to get the drop down list and arrow in the list to change perspective. This causes the perspective to change immediately - aside - shouldn't Eclipse use default selection rather than selection to determine that the combo box has changed value? After the perspective has changed, hit Ctrl Tab and you get a Widget is disposed error.
I believe that items are being set in the Tab list by Eclipse, then when the perspective changes, the items are being disposed but the TabList is not being updated.
Get the following log:

Bug.Summery: javadoc help - incorrect (?) on @exception
javadoc help - incorrect (?) on @exception + @throws
When toolbar has focus, can't use mnemonics for File menus
Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse 20020122-I
In Eclipse, tab to the Toolbar (top or side). Try to activate the File menu using 'Alt F'. Nothing happens. Tab so that the focus is in something other than the toolbar. Try to activate File menu using 'Alt F'. The file menu opens. Works correctly on linux-motif. This is a bug in Windows. The tool bar window proc does not pass WM_SYSCHAR to the DefWindowProc.
Fixed > 20020122.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Eclipse 20020122-I
In Eclipse, tab to the Toolbar (top or side). Try to activate the File menu using 'Alt F'. Nothing happens. Tab so that the focus is in something other than the toolbar. Try to activate File menu using 'Alt F'. The file menu opens. Works correctly on linux-motif. This is a bug in Windows. The tool bar window proc does not pass WM_SYSCHAR to the DefWindowProc.
Fixed > 20020122.

Bug.Summery: Loss of connection to 1.4 VM
Bug.WithStack: When running Eclipse on JDK1.4, and debugging a target program on JDK1.4, if I suspend at a breakpoint, and wait about 30 seconds, the debugger can no longer communicate with the target program. The target program eventually resumes on its own. If I run Eclipse on a 1.3 VM and debug a target program on a 1.4VM the problem does not occurr. Problem does not occurr if I do a remote attach. Using the new JDK1.4rc this problem no longer occurrs. The problem existed with JDK1.4b3. *** Bug 7508 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Bug.WithOutStack: When running Eclipse on JDK1.4, and debugging a target program on JDK1.4, if I suspend at a breakpoint, and wait about 30 seconds, the debugger can no longer communicate with the target program. The target program eventually resumes on its own. If I run Eclipse on a 1.3 VM and debug a target program on a 1.4VM the problem does not occurr. Problem does not occurr if I do a remote attach. Actually Cntr-Tab works. However, it could be made easier :-) Ctrl-Tab is used for tabbing between views. Users expect the tab to be the key used for dialog navigation. Usuability rather than accessibility issue as it is now possible to use the keyboard Works for me in 20020601
Bug.WithOutStack: The Add From Local History dialog is inaccessible from the keyboard. If you open it and hit tab the key is ignored so none of the widgets can be access from the keyboard. Actually Cntr-Tab works. However, it could be made easier :-) Ctrl-Tab is used for tabbing between views. Users expect the tab to be the key used for dialog navigation. Usuability rather than accessibility issue as it is now possible to use the keyboard Works for me in 20020601

Bug.Summery: Incorrect error message when JRE is missing

Lines.Line: 1. Installed Eclipse at c:\eclipse
2. Installed JRE at c:\jre
3. On command line, from directory "c:\eclipse", entered "eclipse -vm
d:/jre/bin/java"

Bug.WithStack:
1. Installed Eclipse at c:\eclipse 2. Installed JRE at c:\jre 3. On command line, from directory "c:\eclipse", entered "eclipse -vm d:/jre/bin/java"
Error message:
No such file or directory c:\eclipse\jre\bin\java.exe
Note that the path in the error message is different from the one specified on the command line (different drive and different directory).
This bug was solved as part of the 2.0 startup sequence rework (http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=12772)
The error message displayed when a JVM cannot be found is more descriptive (see example in http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=12862)
Bug.WithOutStack:
1. Installed Eclipse at c:\eclipse 2. Installed JRE at c:\jre 3. On command line, from directory "c:\eclipse", entered "eclipse -vm d:/jre/bin/java"
Error message:
No such file or directory c:\eclipse\jre\bin\java.exe
Note that the path in the error message is different from the one specified on the command line (different drive and different directory).
This bug was solved as part of the 2.0 startup sequence rework (http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=12772)
The error message displayed when a JVM cannot be found is more descriptive (see example in http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=12862)

Bug.Summery: IncomaptibleClassChangeError hotswapping field declaration

Lines.Line: (1) Why no error dialog
(2) Should we attempt the hot swap if we know it will fail? (Could we have
known the hotswap would not work?)
1. There is no error dialog because there is no error. I've debugged the JDWP
class redefinition call and the VM does *not* complain. It returns error code 0,
which means there was no problem. This behavior is a feature (bug) of the VM.
- Does not support HCR
- Supports HCR
-- Can redefine classes without restriction
-- Cannot redefine classes without restriction
-- Can add methods
-- Cannot add methods

Bug.WithStack:
I modified var decl in VectorTest to:
protected Vector fEmpty = new Vector();
I added a line breakpint to the field decl, and debugged to the breakpoint. I then changed the decl back to:
protected Vector fEmpty;
All methods in VectorTest showed as "out of synch", but no error dialog appeared. When I resumed the program, the following error appeared in the target's console:
java.lang.IncompatibleClassChangeError at junit.textui.TestRunner.doRun(TestRunner.java:74) at junit.textui.TestRunner.run(TestRunner.java:200) at junit.samples.VectorTest.main(VectorTest.java:19) Exception in thread "main"
(1) Why no error dialog (2) Should we attempt the hot swap if we know it will fail? (Could we have known the hotswap would not work?) 1. There is no error dialog because there is no error. I've debugged the JDWP class redefinition call and the VM does *not* complain. It returns error code 0, which means there was no problem. This behavior is a feature (bug) of the VM.
2. The JDI granularity for HCR support is as follows:
- Does not support HCR - Supports HCR -- Can redefine classes without restriction -- Cannot redefine classes without restriction -- Can add methods -- Cannot add methods
Given this information, we can't detect that the VM won't succeed with your example. Thanks to the fix for Bug 8013, the user is now informed that the top stack frame is obsolete in this test case.
This is as fixed as possible. Please verify.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I modified var decl in VectorTest to:
protected Vector fEmpty = new Vector();
I added a line breakpint to the field decl, and debugged to the breakpoint. I then changed the decl back to:
protected Vector fEmpty;
All methods in VectorTest showed as "out of synch", but no error dialog appeared. When I resumed the program, the following error appeared in the target's console:
Exception in thread "main"
(1) Why no error dialog (2) Should we attempt the hot swap if we know it will fail? (Could we have known the hotswap would not work?) 1. There is no error dialog because there is no error. I've debugged the JDWP class redefinition call and the VM does *not* complain. It returns error code 0, which means there was no problem. This behavior is a feature (bug) of the VM.
2. The JDI granularity for HCR support is as follows:
- Does not support HCR - Supports HCR -- Can redefine classes without restriction -- Cannot redefine classes without restriction -- Can add methods -- Cannot add methods
Given this information, we can't detect that the VM won't succeed with your example. Thanks to the fix for Bug 8013, the user is now informed that the top stack frame is obsolete in this test case.
This is as fixed as possible. Please verify.

Bug.Summery: ProjectBuildWatcher is too invasive
Bug.WithStack:
The builder approach to detecting builds for HCR adds data to the project metadata. This is unacceptable.
The hcr builder should be removed and code should be added to the HCR manager to clean up the metadata of affected project. Fixed. Please verify. Released change to debug-milestone-2 stream. Verified. When are we removing the build watcher stuff from the startup in the JavaHotCodeReplaceManager. It does not handle closed projects. The ProjectBuildWatcher and all references to it needs to be removed. I'm not sure if we can remove this support (i.e. for users with old workspaces). Need to ask John W. Done. Please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The builder approach to detecting builds for HCR adds data to the project metadata. This is unacceptable.
The hcr builder should be removed and code should be added to the HCR manager to clean up the metadata of affected project. Fixed. Please verify. Released change to debug-milestone-2 stream. Verified. When are we removing the build watcher stuff from the startup in the JavaHotCodeReplaceManager. It does not handle closed projects. The ProjectBuildWatcher and all references to it needs to be removed. I'm not sure if we can remove this support (i.e. for users with old workspaces). Need to ask John W. Done. Please verify. Verified.

Bug.Summery: LaunchView toolbar actions not updated on long steps
Bug.WithStack:
20020122 JDK 1.3.1
Perform a step return in a method that will take a long time to complete.
The Thread and stack frames update correctly to indicate the stepping, but the toolbar actions (the step, resume, suspend actions) do not update to reflect the current state.
Same for a long step over.
Time to put back all of the updateButtons calls in the LaunchViewEventHandler My mistake, this is in 20020122++. Fixed as the actions now listen to debug events. Please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
20020122 JDK 1.3.1
Perform a step return in a method that will take a long time to complete.
The Thread and stack frames update correctly to indicate the stepping, but the toolbar actions (the step, resume, suspend actions) do not update to reflect the current state.
Same for a long step over.
Time to put back all of the updateButtons calls in the LaunchViewEventHandler My mistake, this is in 20020122++. Fixed as the actions now listen to debug events. Please verify. Verified.

Bug.Summery: accessibility: focus goes missing in CVS location wizard

- press ctrl+n to launch the New wizard selection dialog
- arrow to CVS, tab to right pane, arrow to Repository Location, Next
- focus is not visibile, and worse, doesn't seem to exist. Pressing Tab does
not make it appear anywhere
- in the Resources perspective click on the Repositories tab
- in the view right-click -> New... -> CVS Repository Location
- note that in the subsequent wizard focus is given to the User Name field

Bug.WithStack:
The no-mouse case, which doesn't work: - in the Resources perspective, arrow onto the Repositories tab - press ctrl+n to launch the New wizard selection dialog - arrow to CVS, tab to right pane, arrow to Repository Location, Next - focus is not visibile, and worse, doesn't seem to exist. Pressing Tab does not make it appear anywhere
The typical mouse case, which works fine: - in the Resources perspective click on the Repositories tab - in the view right-click -> New... -> CVS Repository Location - note that in the subsequent wizard focus is given to the User Name field
I'm not sure if the different paths used in these scenarios could be partially responsible. Verified that you can now tab around in this view. We threw away the native tabbing on Motif and this probably fixed the problem. As the exact view no longer exists in Eclipse, I can't verify it.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The no-mouse case, which doesn't work: - in the Resources perspective, arrow onto the Repositories tab - press ctrl+n to launch the New wizard selection dialog - arrow to CVS, tab to right pane, arrow to Repository Location, Next - focus is not visibile, and worse, doesn't seem to exist. Pressing Tab does not make it appear anywhere
The typical mouse case, which works fine: - in the Resources perspective click on the Repositories tab - in the view right-click -> New... -> CVS Repository Location - note that in the subsequent wizard focus is given to the User Name field
I'm not sure if the different paths used in these scenarios could be partially responsible. Verified that you can now tab around in this view. We threw away the native tabbing on Motif and this probably fixed the problem. As the exact view no longer exists in Eclipse, I can't verify it.

Bug.Summery: [Perspectives] Not all settings are captured when hierarchy perspective is saved
Bug.WithStack:
Open a new type hierarchy perspective.
Select the "F" so fields are not visible. Change the ratio of the type hierarchy vs. the methods list.
Save the perspective.
Open another one, neither of these changes were remembered. The ratio between the panes should be persisted in the memento and remember as a preference when creating new instances. everything is stored, but store memento is only called on exiting workspace. I also think that closing a perspective window should invoke storing the memento.
move to eclipse.ui Consider as a post 2.0 enhancement Should consider as part of making perspectives save their settings immediately, without having to explitly open and close perspectives. Reopen to investigate Yes. Defering saving of UI state like this is confusing. There are currently no plans to work on this feature

Bug.Summery: Self-hosting project for SWT has wrong classpath
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020122
When I add the SWT project using the self-hosting tool, it indicates a warning in the task list: Missing library: /org.eclipse.swt/ws/win32/swt-pi.jar.
The build path property page shows: swt-pi.jar - \org.eclipse.swt\ws\win32 swt.jar - org.eclipse.swt/ws/win32 ...
SWT's plugin.xml has: <library name="$ws$/swt-pi.jar"> <export name="*"/> </library> <library name="$ws$/swt.jar"> <export name="*"/> </library>
Why does the self-hosting plugin introduce an absolute path for swt-pi.jar? Even more curious, why does it get it right for swt.jar? Each binary project must have its own build path set so that projects can be built when source projects reference binary projects. In the case of SWT, swt.jar is present so it is correctly resolved, but swt-pi.jar is only applicable to Linux GTK. This is a temporary solution (the JAR will be moved to a fragment that will only be shipped for the right platform/window system combination).
A bug explaining this already exists: 7666
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 7666 ***

Bug.Summery: Each debug launch opens new Debug Perspective
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020109 WinNT 4.0 SP6 Recent changes to Workbench preferences leads to a proliferation of Debug perspectives. In order to be able to open multiple perspective windows, I have had to uncheck "Reuse Perspectives with same input" My preference for "Open a new Perspective" is set to "In a new window". This allows me to open multiple Java perspectives. However, it also leads to the creation of a new Debug perspective every time I perform a debug launch from one of my Java perspectives. It would be nice if a debug launch from a Java perspective worked like a debug launch from a Debug perspective, the Debug perspective is reused. At minimum an option should be added to allow for Debug Perspective reuse.

Bug.Summery: Walkback in styledtext when resizing window

Lines.Line: 1. Which build was this with?
2. Did you have the file open in the default Java editor?
3. Do you actually see any wrapped lines?
4. Is the horizontal scroll bar visible before you walkback (I'm assuming you
get an internal error).
2. Yes.
3. I don't remember.
4. I don't remember.

Bug.WithStack:
Had .java file open. Resized workbench. Got walkback. It's attached, as netscape won't let me paste. Created attachment 250 Stack Can't reproduce with 20020123 build. A couple of questions: 1. Which build was this with? 2. Did you have the file open in the default Java editor? 3. Do you actually see any wrapped lines? 4. Is the horizontal scroll bar visible before you walkback (I'm assuming you get an internal error).
1. 20020122 2. Yes. 3. I don't remember. 4. I don't remember.
For 3 and 4, the workbench window was quite small initially, so it's entirely possible that some lines required the horizontal scrollbar. I just can't recall.
Can't repeat now. James is running on Motif Tried to recreate with 20020123 build on Linux-Motif. Could not. The error is very strange. Based on the walkback, word-wrap would have to be set for the StyledText widget, but WRAP is not a style that is specified for the Java Editor. So we're not sure how the StyledText widget got into a wrapped state. KR checked for uses of the WRAP style in JDT and found none. SWT.WRAP is specified for StyledText in the following two places: org.eclipse.help.internal.ui.ContextHelpDialog.createInfoArea org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.AntConsole.createPartControl
If you open context help (F1) anywhere you will see that the space where the StyledText widget should be is not drawn. There is no log message indicating a walkback. However, if you click in the StyledText widget you get an internal error with the attached stack trace in the log. ContextHelpDialog defines its own wrapping StyledTextContent. This is where the exception occurs.
The Ant Console however does not do its own line wrapping. James, do you remember having the Ant console or the context help open when you got the walkback?
Created attachment 253 StringIndexOutOfBoundsException in org.eclipse.help.internal.ui.StyledLineWrapper.getTextRange I definitely did not have the Ant console open. I did open the help perspective at one point today; I closed the entire perspective shortly thereafter, and it was not open when this walkback occurred, although it could have been open previously. *** Bug 8188 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 8242 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Do you remember any of your views not repainting after you got the walkback? Was your editor still working or did it no longer repaint after the walkback? Did you ever use Ant (i.e., run an Ant script) yesterday or the day before? The Ant console is our only lead at this time. There is no other view that uses a wrapping StyledText that could have resulted in this stack trace. I think the views repainted fine after this. I don't remember whehter the editor still worked or not. I never ever used Ant.
*** Bug 8360 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Ok, looks like we can rule out the AntConsole as being the culprit for this walkback <g>. Checked all references of StyledText to see whether there's a place that creates a StyledText with bogus styles (e.g., SWT.CASCADE which is the same as SWT.WRAP). They are all calling it with proper styles. *** Bug 8380 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 8382 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Note that a PR has been opened against the Help component for the StringIndexOutOfBoundsException. This is a Help bug not a StyledText bug.
http://dev.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=8398
The initial problem of this PR (walkback when resizing) is unrelated to the Help bug (as far as we know) and has not been able to be reproduced. Checked write references to caretLine, which is used in StyledText.wordWrapResize to call WrappedContent.getLine. I don't see how it could get out of range (the exception indicates it was one line past the last line) other than WrappedContent having an inconsistent visualLineCount. The exception James got could happen if the visualLineCount is greater than the actual number of visual (wrapped) lines. Likewise I didn't find anything suspicious with regard to the visualLineCount. I just noticed bug 9191. Is it possible that this walkback occurred in the new CVS Console? That would explain why I couldn't find any WRAP users other than Help and the Ant Console.
Yes, it is certainly possible; I likely would have had it open at the time. There is something fundamentally wrong with the CVS console. However, none of the other duplicate bugs above would have been related to the CVS console as none of those people were using it. The CVS console is on my list of things to get to the bottom of, I'll let you know if I see this again.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 9191 ***

Bug.Summery: Self encapsulate field: No setter created

Lines.Line: 1. Open junit.framework.TestCase
2. Apply 'Self encapsulate field' on fName
3. It only creates the getter, but no setter.
This is on purpose since the field 'fName' is final and therefore you can't
assign a value to it. Generating a setter would result in a compiler error.

Bug.WithStack:
1. Open junit.framework.TestCase 2. Apply 'Self encapsulate field' on fName 3. It only creates the getter, but no setter. This is on purpose since the field 'fName' is final and therefore you can't assign a value to it. Generating a setter would result in a compiler error.
Closing
Bug.WithOutStack:
1. Open junit.framework.TestCase 2. Apply 'Self encapsulate field' on fName 3. It only creates the getter, but no setter. This is on purpose since the field 'fName' is final and therefore you can't assign a value to it. Generating a setter would result in a compiler error.
Closing

Bug.Summery: VCM presents outgoing changes where only incoming one should appear
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020122
If sync'ed up with a particular stream (HEAD), then load a previous version of a given project (e.g. the very last one on the same branch, when a few changes got released since then), and synchronize again with the stream.
You'll see that all changes are listed as outgoing ones, when I would expect to be able to catchup with these instead.
I think this is another instance of the fact that VCM wants to decide for me whether it is outgoing or incoming, when I should be offered to do both, depending on my context (a warning for the non-natural one is fine). When you load a previous version in this case, it is assumed you are replacing the resources with those you have loaded. When you sync, you get outgoing changes on all resources.
In the new code-base, loading a version will "freeze" you on that version until you load HEAD (or a branch) again, just as with other csv clients. This means that syncing on a loaded version will show no changes. Also note that with the new sync view improvements, it is possible to override the direction of any change. (you will be warned before performing "non- natural" operations).
Can this PR be closed? The possibility of overriding suggested actions is perfect. I am happy again. Closing.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020122
If sync'ed up with a particular stream (HEAD), then load a previous version of a given project (e.g. the very last one on the same branch, when a few changes got released since then), and synchronize again with the stream.
You'll see that all changes are listed as outgoing ones, when I would expect to be able to catchup with these instead.
I think this is another instance of the fact that VCM wants to decide for me whether it is outgoing or incoming, when I should be offered to do both, depending on my context (a warning for the non-natural one is fine). When you load a previous version in this case, it is assumed you are replacing the resources with those you have loaded. When you sync, you get outgoing changes on all resources.
In the new code-base, loading a version will "freeze" you on that version until you load HEAD (or a branch) again, just as with other csv clients. This means that syncing on a loaded version will show no changes. Also note that with the new sync view improvements, it is possible to override the direction of any change. (you will be warned before performing "non- natural" operations).
Can this PR be closed? The possibility of overriding suggested actions is perfect. I am happy again. Closing.

Bug.Summery: accessibility: shift+F10 does not display view menu

Lines.Line: - go to the Navigator view in Resource perspective
- press shift+F10
- on Windows this displays the view's context menu, on Motif it doesn't
- without this context menu items are not accessible through the keyboard
Shift+F10 is the key sequence on Windows. What is the standard key sequence on
Motif? If there is none, we could consider supporting Shift+F10.

Bug.WithStack: - go to the Navigator view in Resource perspective - press shift+F10 - on Windows this displays the view's context menu, on Motif it doesn't - without this context menu items are not accessible through the keyboard Shift+F10 is the key sequence on Windows. What is the standard key sequence on Motif? If there is none, we could consider supporting Shift+F10. Fixed > 20020201.

What is the standard key sequence on Motif? If there is none, we could consider supporting Shift+F10. Fixed > 20020201.

Bug.Summery: Task List should have a way to see an error
Bug.WithStack: The Task List should have a way to view the entire contents of an error -either in a dialog or in some sort of better set up help (F1 is a natural choice). Pls confirm that this is now possible. Then move to JDT for their consideration. It is shown in the status bar and in the properties dialog.
